questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with multibacillary leprosy. For how long should she be treated and monitored for relapse, respectively?
questions.solution:
A patient with multibacillary leprosy should be treated for 12 months and monitored for relapse for at least 5 years.

Leprosy is a chronic infectious disease that mainly affects the skin, the peripheral nerves, upper respiratory tract mucosa, and the eyes caused by Mycobacterium leprae. If left untreated, it can lead to permanent damage to the skin, nerves, limbs, and eyes.

Leprosy is classified as paucibacillary (PB) or multibacillary (MB). Paucibacillary leprosy refers to cases with 1-5 skin lesions, no or only 1 involved nerve, with no bacilli in a skin smear. Multibacillary leprosy refers to cases with >5 skin lesions, with >1 nerve involvement, or with the presence of bacilli in the skin smear, irrespective of the number of skin lesions.

WHO recommends multidrug therapy (MDT) for the treatment of leprosy. The currently recommended MDT regimen includes dapsone, rifampicin and clofazimine. It is given for 6 months in paucibacillary leprosy and 12 months for multibacillary cases. 

The majority of the cases are cured following MDT, however, relapse may occur. A multibacillary patient has to be monitored for 5 years and the paucibacillary patient has to be monitored for 2 years after completion of treatment.

The blister pack provided for the treatment of multibacillary leprosy is shown below.

questions.text: In extra dural haemorrhage lucid interval is seen in
questions.solution:
• In extra dural haemorrhage lucid interval is seen in 30-40% of cases.
  • Lucid interval is not seen if the injury of the brain is sufficiently great because of the overlapping of unconsciousness due to brain injury and due to the presence of extra dural haemorrhage.

questions.text: What percentage of drug given will be eliminated by first order kinetics after 4 half lives?
questions.solution:
• In first order kinetics ,  the rate of elimination of drug is directly proportional to the drug concentration.
  • Rate of clearance remains constant.
Half life Elimination (%)
First 50
Second 75
Third 87.5
Fourth 93.75

questions.text: Middle ear transformer ratio is
questions.solution:
• Effective vibratory area of TM: 45 mm2
  • Footplate area: 3.2 mm2
  • Areal ratio: 14:1
  • Lever ratio (ossicles): 1.3:1
  • Total transformer ratio 14 × 1.3 = 18.2:1 or 18:1

Note: This is a controversial topic. There are two different schools of thought regarding the effective vibratory area of the tympanic membrane. 
i) One considers the effective area of the tympanic membrane to be 45mm2 giving a total ratio of 18:1
ii) The second one by Wever and Lawrence considers the effective area to be 55mm2, giving a total ratio of 22:1.

questions.text: Size of airborne droplet nuclei is usually less than or equal to:
questions.solution:
• Droplet nuclei are sized less than or equal to 5 microns. 
  • They are the dried residue of infectious droplets and are capable to indirect airborne transmission of diseases like tuberculosis, influenza, chicken pox, measles, etc. 
  • They can also be generated using atomizing devices. 
  • These small particles are capable to travelling to the alveoli and getting retained there.

questions.text: Number of carbon atoms in Palmitic acid?
questions.solution:
The formula for Palmitic Acid is: CH3(CH2)14COOH. It has 16 carbon atoms.

Few examples of fatty acids with their carbon atom content numbers –

  • Acetic acid 2
  • Butyric acid 4
  • Valeric acid 5
  • Caproic acid 6
  • Lauricacid12
  • Myristicacid 14
  • Palmitic acid 16
  • Stearic acid 18

questions.text: The method of ulcer healing shown below generates a pressure of
questions.solution:
The image above shows the vacuum-assisted closure of an ulcer.

It creates a negative pressure of 125 mm Hg to promote the formation of healthy granulation tissue.

It acts by

  • Reducing tissue edema
  • Clearing interstitial fluid
  • Improves perfusion and increases the healing process

questions.text: Diazepam is   ____  % plasma bound?
questions.solution: • Diazepam and warfarin are 99% plasma bound.

questions.text: Uteroplacental blood flow at term is:
questions.solution:
The uteroplacental blood flow at term is 700-900ml/min.

Maternal blood within the intervillous space is the primary unit of maternal-fetal transfer. The substances transferred from mother to fetus first enter the intervillous space and are then transported to the syncytiotrophoblast.

Intervillous and uteroplacental blood flow increases throught the 1st trimester of normal pregnancies. At term the residual volume of intervillous space is 140ml.

The uteroplacental blood flow near term has been estimated to be 700-900ml/min, with most of the blood going to the intervillous space.

questions.text: Nasal cycle which is rhythmic congestion and decongestion occurs every
questions.solution: • Nasal cycle - Nasal mucosa undergoes rhythmic cyclical congestion and decongestion, thus controlling the airflow through nasal chambers. Nasal cycle varies every 2½–4 h and may be characteristic of an individual.

questions.text: Arachidonic acid contains how many double bonds?
questions.solution: Arachidonic acids contains 4 double bonds in it’s structure.

questions.text: The following suture material gets absorbed in how many days?
questions.solution: The image shows a violet color braided multifilament suture material which is vicryl (polyglactin). It gets absorbed completely in 60-90 days.

questions.text: The days of isolation recommended for German measles is:
questions.solution: No isolation period is required for rubella or German measles except that women who are in their 1st trimester or sexually active or non-immune without contraception usage should not be exposed.

questions.text: According to Krogman’s degree of accuracy of sexing skeletal remains, degree of accuracy when skull alone is used is
questions.solution:
According to Krogman, the degree of accuracy of sexing adult skeletal remains using skull is 90%. Krogman’s degree of accuracy in sexing adult skeletal remains: 

  • Entire skeleton – 100% 
  • Pelvis alone – 95% 
  • Skull alone – 90% 
  • Pelvis plus skull – 98% 
  • Long bones alone – 80%

questions.text: Complete anatomical obliteration of the ductus arteriosus occurs at
questions.solution:
• Closure of the ductus arteriosus by contraction of its muscular wall occurs almost immediately after birth. It is mediated by bradykinin.
  • Complete anatomical obliteration by proliferation of the intima is thought to take 1 to 3 months.
  • In the adult, the obliterated ductus arteriosus forms the ligamentum arteriosum.

questions.text: What is the least crown heel length to be included in the perinatal mortality rate if birth weight and gestational period are not available?
questions.solution:
Perinatal mortality rate (PMR) includes stillbirths which are categorized as late foetal deaths.

Perinatal mortality Rate (PMR) = (Late fetal deaths + early neonatal deaths/ Late fetal deaths + live births) x 1000

Related Pearl: Perinatal Mortality Rate

  • The term ‘perinatal mortality’ includes both late fetal death (stillbirths) and early neonatal deaths.
  • Babies chosen for inclusion in perinatal statistics should be above a minimum birth weight (1000g at birth). If the birth weight is not available, a gestation period of at least 28 weeks should be used (as the weight at 28 weeks corresponds to 1000g). If both are not available, then crown to heel length of at least 35cm should be used.
  • Generally, the PMR = Late fetal deaths and early neonatal deaths weighing over 1000g at birth x 1000/Total births(live+dead) weighing over 1000g at birth.
  • The PMR is the yard-stick of obstetric and pediatric care before and around the time of birth.
  • The PMR of India (2016) is 24 per 1000 births.
  • The main causes of perinatal mortality are intrauterine and birth asphyxia, low birth weight, birth trauma, and intrauterine/neonatal infections.

Please note that the actual perinatal period commences from the 22nd week of life, but at that time the fetus weighs only about 500g.

Therefore, only for statistical calculations and international comparisons, to calculate the perinatal mortality rate, the period from the 28th week of life is taken, as then the baby weighs about 1000g. As mentioned, babies included in the perinatal statistics must weigh above 1000g.

questions.text: To which generation of IUDs does Lippes Loop belong to?
questions.solution:
• Lippes Loop belongs to 1st generation IUDs.
  • It comes in 4 sizes – A, B, C and D.
  • It is an S shaped device, usually made of polyethylene.
  • The tail which is usually made of fine nylon, projects into the vagina after insertion.
  • The larger loops have higher rates of removal due to side effects but have greater anti-fertility effects.
  • Larger loops are usually used in multiparous women.
  • The Lippes Loop has minimal amount of barium sulphate in them to allow for X-ray observation.

questions.text: Approximately when does the structural development of the heart begin?
questions.solution:
• It is approximately after 16 days after fertilization the structural development of the heart begins. The most appropriate answer is 15 days.
  • On approximately day 16, heart progenitor cells migrate through the primitive streak where they establish a horseshoe-shaped region in the splanchnic layer of lateral plate mesoderm called the primary heart field (PHF).

questions.text: Intraorbital part of optic nerve measures about
questions.solution:
Intraorbital part is the longest part of optic nerve.

 It measures from 25 mm to 30 mm.

Length of the optic nerve ranges from 3.5 cm to 5.5 cm.

Parts of optic nerve :

Parts Length
Intraocular part 1 mm
Intraorbital part 30 mm
Intracanalicular part 6 mm
Intracranial part 10 mm

questions.text: Total number of amino acids encoded by the human genetic code
questions.solution:
• 20 amino acids are encoded by human genetic code
  • Although more than 300 amino acids occur in nature, proteins are synthesized almost exclusively from the set of 20 L-alpha amino acids encoded by nucleotide triplets called CODONS.

questions.text: What is the resting membrane potential of the sinoatrial (SA) node?
questions.solution:
The resting membrane potential (RMP) of the sinoatrial (SA) node is -55 to-60 millivolts.

questions.text: Duramater is supplied by all cranial nerves except
questions.solution:
CN 4(trochlear nerve) is a pure motor nerve to supply the superior oblique muscle.

Innervation of the dura mater is derived mainly from three sources:

  • Three divisions of the trigeminal nerve
  • Second and third cervical spinal nerves
  • The cervical sympathetic trunk
  • Meningeal branches arising from the vagus, hypoglossal nerves, facial and glossopharyngeal nerves.

questions.text: In Broca index for calculation of ideal body weight, the formula is height (in cms) minus:
questions.solution:
• Broca index is given by height (in cms) minus 100.
  • For example, if the person’s height is 178 cms, his ideal weight would be 78 kgs.

questions.text: A waist-hip ratio higher than what is considered high risk for cardiovascular disease in men?
questions.solution:
• Waist-hip ratio can indicate fat accumulation and a high ratio can be a risk factor for cardiovascular disease.
  • In men, a WHR of more than 1.0 and in women, more than 0.85 are considered as a potential risk factor.

questions.text: How many molecules of acetyl-CoA are produced in oxidation of palmitic acid (C16), which involves seven rounds of oxidation?
questions.solution:
• In oxidation of palmitic acid (C16),8 molecules of acetyl-CoA are produced.
  • In the Beta-oxidation pathway, two carbons at a time are cleaved from acyl-CoA molecules, starting at the carboxyl end. The two-carbon units formed are acetyl-CoA; thus, palmitoyl-CoA forms eight acetyl-CoA molecules.

questions.text: Density of endothelial cells in corneal endothelium in  adult is about ?
questions.solution:
• The cell density of corneal endothelium is around 3000 cells / mm2 in young adults which decreases with age.
  • When endothelial cells are damaged they do not proliferate, instead they undergo polymegathism and pleomorphism.

questions.text: Sleep apnoea is defined as temporary pause in breathing during sleep for atleast ?
questions.solution:
• Sleep apnoea is defined as breath cessation for at least 10 seconds.
  • Sleep apnoea may be:
    • Central
    • Obstructive
  • Features:
    • Obese
    • Snoring
    • Daytime somnolence
  • Complications:
    • Pulmonary hypertension
    • Type II respiratory failure
  • Investigations- Polysomnography
  • Management:
    • Weight reduction
    • CPAP via a nasal mask during sleep
  • AHI (Apnoea Hypopnoea Index)= No. of apneas+hypopnoeas / hour of sleep
  • RDI(Respiratory Disturbance Index)= Number of apneas + hypopneas + RERAs/ hour of sleep         
  • Obstructive sleep apnoea/ hypopnoea syndrome severity scale:
OSAHS grade No. of AHI events / hr
Mild 5-14
Moderate 15-29
Severe ≥30

*Respiratory effort–related arousal (RERA)

questions.text: Attachment of Sibson's fascia is at vertebra
questions.solution:
• The suprapleural membrane is the Sibson's fascia which attaches to the transverse processes of the C7 vertebra.
  • It is attached anteriorly to the inner border of the first rib, and posteriorly to the anterior border of the transverse process of the C7 vertebra.

questions.text: In electro-oculography, an Arden index value of above what is considered normal?
questions.solution:
• An Arden index value of above 185 is considered normal and below 150 is abnormal.
  • Arden index is used in electro-oculography (EOG).
  • In EOG, electrodes are used to pick up changes in ocular potential when the eyes are moved and these changes are recorded in accordance with changes in illumination.
  • It indicates the activity of the pigmentary epithelium and the outer segments of visual receptors.
  • Arden index is the ratio of the light peak over the dark trough.
  • This technique is of value in diagnosing retinal diseases.

questions.solution:

questions.text: Voyeurism is punished under
questions.solution:
Voyeurism is punishable under BNS Sec 77 (354C IPC) with imprisonment of not less than 1 year, which may extend upto 3 years. For the second and subsequent offenses imprisonment of 3-7 years is given.

Other options:

Option A- BNS Sec 75 (354A IPC) – Defines and penalises sexual harassment.

Option B- BNS Sec 76 (354B IPC) – deals with assault or use of criminal force on a woman with intent to disrobe her. Such an act can be punished with an imprisonment of 3 years, which may extend up to 7 years, and also a fine.

Option D- BNS Sec 78 (354D IPC) – deals with stalking.

questions.solution:
• The maximum safe cold storage time for kidney transplant is about 36 hours.

questions.text: The spinal injuries are immediately fatal if the fracture occurs above the level of which cervical vertebrae?
questions.solution:
The spinal injuries are immediately fatal if the fracture occurs above the level of the C4 cervical vertebra. 

The origin of the phrenic nerve or the spinal respiratory centre is mainly formed by the C4 spinal cord segment, with minor contributions from C3 and C5 segments. Thus injury to the spinal cord above C4 vertebral level can be rapidly fatal from disruption of cardiorespiratory regulation centres.

The most common part of the spine injured is the upper cervical vertebrae (C1–C4). It accounts for 2/3rd of adult spine injuries. 

The order of frequency of injury to the spinal cord is cervical > thoracolumbar > lumbar > thoracic > sacral level.

questions.text: Under normal circumstances, the percentage of hair follicles on the human scalp, present in anagen of the hair cycle are _______
questions.solution:
Hair Cycle is usually described under three phases: Anagen, Catagen and Telogen. At any given time, under normal circumstances, 80–90% of hair follicles on the human scalp are in anagen phase of growth.

Related Pearl: Hair Cycle

Hair follicles undergo a repetitive sequence of growth and the rest is known as the hair cycle. Hair Cycle is usually described under three phases: Anagen, Catagen, and Telogen.

1. Anagen

  • The period of active hair growth is known as anagen and the duration of this phase is responsible for determining the final length of the hair.
  • The entry of a resting hair follicle into anagen is heralded by the onset of mitotic activity in epithelial cells overlying the dermal papilla at the base of the follicle (the secondary epithelial germ).
  • Under normal circumstances, 80–90% of hair follicles on the human scalp are in anagen at any one time.
  • Anagen can continue for several years.

Fig 1. Scalp hair follicle in the anagen II stage of development

Fig 2.  Anagen hair bulb. Co, hair cortex; Cu, hair cuticle; DP, dermal papilla; DS, dermal sheath; He, Henle layer; HM, hair matrix; Hu, Huxley layer; IRSCu, inner root sheath cuticle; Me, melanocyte; ORS, outer root sheath

2. Catagen

  • At the end of anagen, epithelial cell division declines and ceases, and the follicle enters an involutionary phase known as catagen.
  • During catagen, the proximal end of the hair shaft keratinizes to form a club-shaped structure and the lower part of the follicle involutes by apoptosis.
  • The basement membrane surrounding the follicle becomes thickened and corrugated to form the ‘glassy membrane’.
  • It lasts for about 10 days.

Fig 3.  Human hair follicle in mid-catagen. There is a prominent glassy membrane surrounding the regressing epithelial column. The dermal papilla is rounded and condensed. 

3. Telogen

  • It is the time period between catagen and the next anagen.
  • It lasts for about 3 months.
  • Club hair is eventually shed through an active process called exogen.
  • In the human scalp, hair follicles may remain in a state of latency, also known as kenogen, for a pro­longed period after the club hair is shed.

questions.text: Time interval between acute and persistent psychotic disease is
questions.solution:
If symptoms are for less than 1 months, it is transient psychotic disorder and if there are for more than 1 months, it is persistent psychotic disorder (persistent delusional disorder).

Diagnosic criteria for delusional disorder (Persistent delusion disorder) has different durations in DSM IV and ICD-10 :-

  1. According to DSM IV, symptoms (Non bizzare delusion) should be for > 1 months.
  2. According to ICD-10, Symptoms should be for > 3 months.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man living in the UK is planning to travel to India. His doctor advises him to take the typhoral vaccine. Which of the following days are included in the schedule?
questions.solution:
Days 1, 3, and 5 are included in the schedule of typhoral vaccine, if day 1 is the first dose of the vaccine. In other words, it should be given on alternate days.

Typhoral vaccine is a live oral typhoid vaccine containing a mutated Salmonella typhi Ty21a. This strain lacks the enzyme UDP- galactose- 4 epimerases. It initiates an infection after ingestion, but the strain is self-destructible. Hence does not cause a serious illness.  

The schedule is 3 doses on alternate days, i.e., on the 1st, 3rd, and 5th day. The capsules are enteric coated and taken an hour before food. No antibiotic should be taken during the schedule.

questions.text: A young girl presents with an abrasion over the forearm. On examination, it appears as a reddish-brown scab. The likely age of the abrasion is:
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the abrasion appears as a reddish-brown scab, so the likely age of the abrasion is 2-3 days.

Age of abrasions:

Color of scab Duration
Bright red 12-24 hrs
Reddish-brown 2-3 days
Dark brown to brownish-black       4-7 days
Scab dries shrinks and falls off         After 7 days

An abrasion is the most superficial of injuries and does not penetrate the full thickness of the epidermis. A pure abrasion does not bleed, as blood vessels are confined to the dermis. However, the dermal papillae are corrugated in nature. Thus, many abrasions enter the dermis and bleeding commonly occurs.

Types of abrasions: 

  • Linear abrasions/ scratches - caused by relative movement of a pointed object on the skin
    • Examples - abrasion caused by nails, thorns, or the point of a sword or knife
  • Grazed/ sliding/ scrapping/ grinding abrasion/ brush burns - caused by relative movement of a rough surface on a wide area of skin. They are the most common type of abrasions
    • Examples - abrasion caused by falls, a victim being dragged on the ground, road traffic accidents
  • Imprint/ patterned abrasions - caused by the impact of a rigid hard rough surface over a localized area of the skin without any movement
    • Examples - abrasion caused by tire, grills, bicycle chain, bite marks
  • Friction/ pressure abrasion - is caused by crushing of the superficial layers of the epidermis
    • Examples - abrasion caused by ligature marks around the neck in hanging

Related Pearl: Age of bruise and abrasion

Age and color change of bruise/contusion:

 

Colour Due to Duration  
Red Haemoglobin (fresh blood) Fresh  
Blue Deoxygenated haemoglobin Few hours to 3 days 
Bluish black/ brown Hemosiderin 4th day  
Green Hematoidin 5 to 6 days 
Yellow Bilirubin 7 to 12 days 
Normal colour Pigment removed by phagocytes  2 weeks

 

The image given below shows the age and colour change of bruise:

 

Age of abrasion:

Colour of scab Duration
Bright red 12-24 hrs
Reddish brown 2-3 days
Dark brown to brownish black 4-7 days
Scab dries shrinks and falls off After 7 days

questions.text: Which of the following percentages represent a VLDL?

choices.text: 20% TAGs and 60% cholesterol and cholesteryl esters
50% TAGs and 50% cholesterol and cholesteryl esters
60% TAGs and 20% cholesterol and cholesteryl esters
40% TAGs and 30% cholesterol and cholesteryl esters

questions.solution:
• VLDL are composed predominantly of endogenous triacylglycerol (approximately 60%), 20% cholesterol and cholesteryl esters
  • VLDLs are produced in the liver and their function is to carry this lipid from the liver (site of synthesis) to the peripheral tissues.

questions.text: What is the recommended interval in months for administration of a live vaccine after administration of normal human immunoglobulin (NHIG)?
questions.solution:
• Live vaccines must not be given simultaneously with normal human immunoglobulin. It must be given at least 3 weeks before or 3 months after a NHIG injection.
  • Immunoglobulins can reduce or block the immune response to live vaccines.

questions.text: Multidose vaccine vials must be stored after opening at a temperature of:
questions.solution: Most multidose vaccine vials that are opened must be stored at a temperature of 2 to 8 degree Celsius during an immunization session or they must be used within 6 hours of opening.

questions.text: The number of axostyles, and flagella possessed by trophozoite form of giardia lamblia are respectively ________
questions.solution:
The number of axostyles, and flagella possessed by trophozoite form of giardia lamblia are respectively 1 pair, 4 pairs.

  • The trophozoite form of giardia lamblia is in the shape of tennis racket or “Heart shaped” or “pyriform shaped”.
  • It is bilaterally symmetrical and possesses
    • Nuclei – 1 Pair
    • Flagella – 4 Pairs
    • Blepharoplast/Basal bodies from which flagella arises – 4 Pairs
    • Axostyles running along the midline – 1 Pair
    • Parabasal or median bodies - 2
  • The image below shows structure of Giardia lamblia Trophozoite

questions.text: How many fully frozen ice packs must a vaccine carrier have?
questions.solution:
• A vaccine carrier should have 4 fully frozen ice packs that line the sides.
  • Vaccine carriers are used for transporting the vaccines and never for storage.

questions.text: The amount of bleaching powder per litre necessary to disinfect stool is:
questions.solution:

questions.text:
Dowry death is defined under which section of the law?

IPC - Indian Penal Code

CrPC - Criminal Procedure Code

BNS - BHARATIYA NYAYA SANHITA

BNSS - BHARATIYA NAGARIK SURAKSHA SANHITA
questions.solution:
Dowry Death is defined under section BNS 80 (304B IPC).

According to this if a husband or his relative subjects the woman to cruelty or harassment in demand of dowry within 7 years of marriage; they shall be deemed to have caused her death.

The punishment for such cases is imprisonment for not less than 7 years but may be extended to life imprisonment.

Other options:

Option A: Section BNS 106 (304A IPC): Causing death by negligence

Option C: Section BNSS 194 (174 CrPC): Police inquest

Option D: Section BNSS 196 (176 CrPC): Magistrate inquest

questions.text: A new family is a nuclear family that is younger than how many years?
questions.solution:
• The term new family is applied when nuclear families are younger than 10 years and consist of parents and children.
  • A nuclear family or elementary family consists of only the married couple and their offspring while they are dependants.

questions.text: The average blood loss in Ancylostomiasis with Ancylostoma duodenale, per worm is ____
questions.solution:
Ancylostomiasis is a hookworm disease caused by infection with Ancylostoma hookworms.

Average blood loss by the host per worm per day is 0.03 mL with Necator americanus and 0.2 mL with Ancylostoma duodenale.

questions.text: An estimation of the poverty line is the expenditure required, in rural areas, for a daily calorie intake of _________ per person
questions.solution: An estimate of the poverty line is the expenditure required for a daily calorie intake of 2100 in urban areas and 2400 in rural areas, per person.
